title: WCAS POLI_SCI 307-0-20 Deportation Law and Politics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class we will read texts that allow us to follow the history and theory of deportation laws and practices from the American colonies of England through contemporary policies and debates. The class will read original texts and histories about deportation policies, and compare these with our country's current laws, practices, theories, and debates.
This course will require students to attend at least four hours of immigration court hearings in downtown Chicago on at least two occasions. Hearings begin at 8:30 a.m.. and students need to be there promptly. (The court is easily accessible by public transportation.)

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students should be able to understand deportation laws and their history, and defend their views of whether these policies are just or unjust.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: seminar, two required visits to immigration court in downtown Chicago

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be weekly reading assignments and two memoranda addressed to a government agency or member of Congress about deportation laws or their implementation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Tentative list:
Daniel Kanstroom, Deportation Nation: Outsiders in American History (Harvard University Press,
2007, paper 2010)

Nicholas De Genova and Nathalie Peutz, ed. The Deportation Regime (Duke University Press, 2010)
Mark Dow, American Gulag: Inside U.S. Immigration Prisons (University of California Press, 2005)

All additional assigned readings as well as class assignments are available in a REQUIRED course
reader. This may be purchased at Quartet Copies, 825 Clark Street, Evanston.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class is required.
